name: Bruges
fun_fact: Fun fact: Bruges has an underground beer pipeline stretching 3.2km through the city to avoid trucks damaging the medieval cobblestones. The 'Bruges Fool' beer gets its name from when Emperor Maximilian witnessed a parade of jesters and locals asked him for a 'madhouse'!

hero_dishes.name: Stoverij (Flemish Beef Stew)
hero_dishes.description: Rich, chunky beef stew slowly cooked for hours in dark Belgian beer, creating a sweet, complex gravy unique to Bruges
hero_dishes.origin_story: This traditional Flemish dish has been a staple of Bruges cuisine for centuries, using local dark beers to tenderize and flavor the meat during long, slow cooking
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Cambrinus (historic brasserie with 400+ Belgian beers), Bistro Brugis (next to Grote Markt)

hero_dishes.name: Moules-frites (Mussels and Fries)
hero_dishes.description: Fresh North Sea mussels steamed in white wine and garlic, served with crispy twice-fried Belgian frites
hero_dishes.origin_story: A quintessential Belgian dish showcasing seafood from the nearby North Sea. The secret to Belgian frites is double-frying in ox fat or lard
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional brasseries throughout Bruges, especially near Grote Markt. Look for places making waffles fresh (not pre-made)

hero_dishes.name: North Sea Shrimp Croquettes
hero_dishes.description: Crispy fried croquettes filled with creamy North Sea shrimp or cheese, found on almost every menu
hero_dishes.origin_story: A Belgian classic using the tiny grey shrimp from the North Sea, prized for their delicate sweetness
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Nearly every restaurant in Bruges serves these. Best enjoyed at authentic local taverns

signature_drinks.name: Brugse Zot
signature_drinks.description: Bruges' own blonde city beer (6% ABV), brewed for 6 generations at De Halve Maan brewery in the city center using 4 malts and 2 hop varieties
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Locals enjoy this at De Halve Maan brewery after the famous tour, or at one of the many beer cafÃ©s. There's also a stronger Brugse Zot Dubbel made with 6 specialty malts

signature_drinks.name: Straffe Hendrik
signature_drinks.description: Strong beer from the same De Halve Maan brewery that brews Brugse Zot, representing 500 years of brewing tradition
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served at the brewery and local taverns. Belgian beer culture was inscribed on UNESCO's Intangible Cultural Heritage list in 2016

food_culture_notes: Never expect a table on Friday/Saturday without a reservation - this small city draws crowds from across Belgium
Avoid restaurants too close to Grote Markt (main square) - venture to side streets for authentic local spots
One local favorite only has menus in Flemish, adding to the authentic experience
Belgian waffles are best from Arlecchino Gelateria (white van on Burg Square) - they make them fresh, not pre-made
Belgian frites are traditionally served with mayonnaise, not ketchup

landmarks: Belfry of Bruges (13th-century tower with 47-bell carillon)
Church of Our Lady (115.6m brick spire - world's 2nd highest)
Half-timbered medieval buildings from Danish period
Cobblestone streets in UNESCO World Heritage historic center
atmosphere: Venice of the North - canal-based medieval city
Flemish Primitives art heritage (Jan van Eyck, Hans Memling)
Procession of the Holy Blood (UNESCO intangible heritage) on Ascension Day
colors: Medieval brick reds and Gothic browns
unique_modern: Craft brewery Fort Lapin just outside center
